metadata.title: Synthesis of NiBTC metal-organic framework thin layers on nickel foam by different electrochemical methods: A comparative study for hydrogen evolution reaction

Fig. 1 FESEM images for electrochemical synthesis of NiBTC by: (a-c) CV method at 5; 10 and 25 mV/s, respectively; (d-g) LSV method at 0.5, 1, and 2 mV/s, respectively; (h) elemental distribution of active materials at 2 mV/s with LSV method. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a-d) TEM and (e-g) HRTEM of NiBTC MOF electrode material by LSV3; (h) Inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) images of the regions A-D in 2 g. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of synthesized NiBTC by LSV with different scan rates: (a) 2; (b) 0.5; (c) 1 and (d) 4 mV/s, respectively. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 FTIR spectrum of synthesized NiBTC by LSV technique (LSV3). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution (inset) of LSV3. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) LSV plots for the HER on bare and modified Ni foams in comparison to platinum disc electrode in 0.1 M NaOH solution (scan rate: 5 mV/s); (b) Tafel plots; (c) Nyquist plots of bare Ni foam and LSV3 in 0.1 M NaOH solution (inset is the fitted equivalent circuit); (d) Chronopotentiogram of LSV3 electrode during 30 h at −20 mA/cm2 to examine the stability of HER. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a, b) FESEM images and (c) elemental mapping of the optimal electrode (LSV3) after the stability test for HER. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 CV plots at different scan rates (Mv/s) in 0.1 M NaOH for (a) bare Ni foam and synthesized NiBTC MOF by electrochemical methods: (b) CV5; (c) CV10; (d) CV25; (e) LSV5 and (f) LSV3, respectively. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Plots for calculating double-layer capacitance (C dl ). Fig. 9 Scheme 1 Representation of electrochemical synthesis procedures. Scheme 1 Table 1 Nomenclature of synthesized electrode materials. Table 1 Electrode name Method Scan rate (mV/s) Potential range (V) CV5 CV 5 0–3 CV10 CV 10 0–3 CV25 CV 25 0–3 LSV3 LSV 2 0–3 LSV5 LSV 2 0–5 Synthesis of NiBTC metal-organic framework thin layers on nickel foam by different electrochemical methods: A comparative study for hydrogen evolution reaction Ali Sadeghi Formal analysis Visualization Validation Writing – original draft a b Ali Ghaffarinejad Supervision Project administration Writing – review & editing a b ⁎ a Research Laboratory of Real Samples Analysis, Faculty of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran 1684613114, Iran Research Laboratory of Real Samples Analysis, Faculty of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology Tehran 1684613114 Iran Research Laboratory of Real Samples Analysis, Faculty of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran 1684613114, Iran b Electroanalytical Chemistry Research Center, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran 1684613114, Iran Electroanalytical Chemistry Research Center, Iran University of Science and Technology Tehran 1684613114 Iran Electroanalytical Chemistry Research Center, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran 1684613114, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author at: Research Laboratory of Real Samples Analysis, Faculty of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran 1684613114, Iran. Research Laboratory of Real Samples Analysis, Faculty of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology Tehran 1684613114 Iran In this study, for the first time two electrochemical synthesis techniques including cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) were used for MOF synthesis. The Ni3(BTC)2 electrocatalyst was synthesized and deposited without any binder, for a short time and at ambient temperature on the nickel foam substrate. Morphology studies showed that the LSV method leads to preserving the 3D structure of nickel foam which promotes the catalytic activity. It should be noted that two parameters, such as voltage range and scan rate, were optimized during the LSV method. Moreover, X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy were used to confirm the MOF's structural integrity. Furthermore, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method verified the porous structure of NiBTC MOF. Additionally, the performance of bare and modified nickel foams was also examined for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) which demonstrated the tremendous potential of NiBTC/Ni foam in HER catalytic activity. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Electrochemical synthesis Hydrogen evolution reaction Metal-organic framework Ni3(BTC)2 Nickel foam Thin film Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The development of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), an area of organic-inorganic hybrid materials, has attracted a lot of attention in recent years. These materials provide high surface areas, adequate pore volumes, and adjustable architectures due to the metal clusters and organic linkers that make up their composition which cause consistent and numerous active sites accompanied by well-defined morphologies to promote electron transfer [1,2]. Because of existing these features, MOFs can be used for a variety of purposes, including chromatography [3,4], gas adsorption and separation [5,6], medication administration [7,8], sensing [9,10], electrocatalysis [11,12], photocatalysis [13], and energy storage [14,15]. Therefore, many techniques for creating these materials, including solvothermal [16], liquid phase [17], evaporation [18], microwave [19], and gel layer [20] were enhanced. As it is obvious, these methods cause the preparation of MOFs which are not controllable and selective and require high magnitudes of vacuum, pressure, and temperature. Additionally, they take a lot of time including numerous stages, and their morphology is not uniform [21]. Contrarily, electrochemical procedures can be controlled by applying voltage and current and are also capable of being carried out at room temperature and pressure while requiring little time for synthesis. Moreover, these techniques received particular attention due to their cost-effectiveness, ease of use, and high sensitivity [22]. The synthesis of MOFs in thin layers can be aided by anodic or cathodic deposition techniques [23,24]. During anodic electrosynthesis, the electrode (anode) is submerged in an electrolyte made of organic linkers. The metal ions are then released while an oxidation voltage is being applied, reacting with organic ligands close to the electrode surface to create a thin layer of MOF. By employing optimal electrochemical conditions, this method was used to conveniently control MOF characteristics [25]. The electrosynthesis of MOF depends on a variety of factors, including the electrolyte, solvent, time, voltage, and current. However, the concentration of metal ions and the size of crystals will be controlled during the change in applied voltage magnitude [26]. Different MOFs, including MIL-53 (Al) [27], MIL-100 (Fe) [28], Ni3(BTC)2 [29], HKUST-1 [30], and ZIF-67 [31] were created using the aforementioned process. Because of increasing concerns about fossil fuels, climate changes, and carbon dioxide emissions, various alternatives such as sustainable and clean energy sources attracted great attention [32,33]. In this way, the high energy density and high combustion heat of hydrogen make it a promising and fascinating fuel source [34]. Thus, producing hydrogen on a wide scale and cheaply could serve as a substitute for fossil fuels [35,36]. This phenomenon caused numerous attempts to use various electrodes for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) as well as the introduction of various types of affordable MOFs [37,38]. Additionally, a variety of materials can be utilized as the substrate, however, nickel metal and foam are regarded as affordable HER catalysts and stable substrates in various electrolytes, respectively [39,40]. The low cost and 3D interconnected porous structure of nickel foam with 99% porosity makes it appropriate for sufficient electrical conductivity with a resistance of 69 nΩ/m [41]. Hence, these aspects lead to a larger surface area and better contact of active materials to the electrolyte which can improve the diffusion of the electrolyte and reduce the agglomeration of electrocatalysts [42,43]. Additionally, due to the existence of metal frames inside of the substrate, the electron transfer length is shorter than the 2D type substrate where the substrate is at the back side of all active materials [44]. Therefore, the combination of MOF and Ni foam can enhance their catalytic activity for HER process and enable their use as electrocatalyst because of the high porosity and wide surface area in the structure of MOF. It should be noticed that various noble metal-based electrocatalysts are used for this goal due to their particular activity and better availability, but their high cost and scarcity limit their further application. Thus, earth-abundant transition metal (e.g.: Ni, Co, …) based electrocatalysts are considered as outstanding alternatives for these materials because they can present high catalytic activity with high specific surface area [45,46]. Hence, this study presented new techniques for the uniform electrosynthesis of MOF while maintaining the porous skeleton of the nickel foam as working and graphite sheet as cheap counter electrodes, respectively. So, for the first time, two electrochemical techniques (CV and LSV) were used for MOF electrosynthesis and were compared. In addition, 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC) (98%) and tributyl methylammonium methyl sulfate (MTBS) (99%) were used as organic linkers to obtain Ni3(BTC)2 ( Scheme 1). Then, based on this composition and techniques, plate-shaped and homogeneous NiBTC MOF nanostructures were prepared by the LSV method which has been verified by FESEM results and performed best as an electrocatalyst in the HER procedure in an alkaline media. Also, important parameters such as scan rate and voltage ranges were optimized during the project. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (BTC) and tributyl methylammonium methyl sulfate (MTBS) were obtained from Acros (Belgium) and Kimiaexir (Iran), respectively. Nickel foam (> 99%) was purchased from Nano-bazar (Iran). Also, absolute ethanol (99%), sodium hydroxide, and hydrochloric acid (37%) were prepared from Merck (Germany). Additionally, deionized water was used for the H2O-EtOH solution. All materials were utilized without further purification and had analytical grades. 2.2 Apparatus and software Electrochemical studies were done by the potentiostat/galvanostat model of Autolab PGSTAT30 (Echo Chemie, B.V. ααand the Netherlands) and the software was Nova version 1.11. Also, impedance analysis was performed by ZView software to obtain an equivalent circuit. The three-electrode system consisted of Ni foam and graphite sheet with a surface area of 0.5 cm2 as working and counter electrodes, respectively accompanied by Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) as reference electrode were used for electrosynthesis of MOF. Moreover, HER processes were performed with the three-electrode system including bare Ni and NiBTC/Ni foams as the working electrodes with a surface area of 0.5 cm2, Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) and Pt rod as reference and counter electrodes, respectively. Nickel foams were immersed in HCl (1 M) in an ultrasonic bath for 5 min, and then they were washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol to remove the surface oxide layer. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was done at ambient temperature (25 °C) by X-ray diffractometer model of Bruker D8 advance (Germany) by Cu–Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5418 Å) generated at 40 kV and 25 mA, and the step time of 0.06°/s. Then, FTIR spectra were taken between 400 and 4000 cm−1 with a Shimadzu S8400 FTIR spectrophotometer. Furthermore, Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) figures were obtained by the FESEM instrument model of VEGA/TESCAN (Czech Republic). Moreover, Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurement was done at 77 K by the BET instrument model of ASAPT micropolitics 2020. 2.3 Electrochemical synthesis of MOF Synthesis of Ni3(BTC)2 was carried out by electrochemical techniques. These techniques were done in the potentiostatic module. Then, the synthesis solution was obtained by dissolving 15 mmol of BTC and 33 mmol of MTBS in 100 mL of EtOH/H2O (with a ratio of 70:30 for EtOH/H2O based on ref [27]). 3 mL of this solution was used for the electrosynthesis of NiBTC MOF. For the cyclic voltammetry test, 0–3 V was used as the potential range accompanied by different scan rates (5, 10, 25 mV/s, cycle number = 1, 5). Also, during LSV, two potential ranges between 0 and 3 V and 0–5 V with three scan rates of 0.5, 1, and 2 mV/s were applied. Table 1 depicts the nomenclature of synthesized electrodes. After the synthesis, the NiBTC/Ni foam was mildly washed with ethanol. For FESEM images, XRD analysis, and FTIR spectroscopy, the samples were dried under the vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface morphology and elemental analysis To characterize MOF morphology on Ni foam, some FESEM images were obtained. First of all, cyclic voltammetry was performed to deposit MOF nanoparticles. Thus, different procedures were programmed to synthesize the MOF, and two important parameters such as scan rate and cycle number were investigated during the processes. It should be noted that all CV tests were performed from 0 to 3 V. Then, 5 mV/s was used for 1 and 5-cycle numbers. As exhibited in Fig. 1a, needle-like NiBTC was obtained by CV test, and increasing the number of cycles not only did not make a homogeneous structure but also led to brittle morphology and exfoliated MOF particles (Fig. S1). Also, this phenomenon happened with utilizing 10 and 25 mV/s as scan rates and nonuniform MOF structure was obtained which resulted in cracking on the particles and unsuitable elemental distribution (Fig. 1b, c). This form of precipitation can ban the penetration of electrolytes to the network of Ni foam and prohibit further application of this composition. In addition, oxidation and reduction of MOF nanoparticles during potential scanning at CV tests reduced the cohesion of active materials and their adhesion to the substrate (Fig. S2, S3). Then, some LSV tests were examined with variations in two parameters such as potential range and scan rate. According to this procedure, different LSV tests were examined by 0.5 and 1 mV/s during 0–3 and 5 V, respectively which illustrated the blocking of Ni foam porosity and unsuitable coverage of the substrate (Fig. 1d, e and S4, S5). Therefore, the LSV test was applied from 0 to 3 V with 2 mV/s to electrosynthesis of NiBTC. As it is obvious in Fig. 1f and g, suitable coverage of MOF particles was obtained by this method that provided sufficient availability of the electrolyte to the Ni foam. In addition, the plate-like morphology of active materials can enhance the surface area and supply appropriate elemental distribution (Fig. 1h). The origin of sulfur was attributed to MTBS which acted as an organic linker. Also, the effect of increasing potential up to 5 V was examined which led to needle-like NiBTC particles and deterioration of nickel foam without sufficient adhesion of active materials to the substrate (Fig. S6). Thus, according to FESEM results and to obtain a thin layer of NiBTC on Ni foam, the LSV method during 0–3 V with 2 mV/s resulted in the best performance. Moreover, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed to interpret the morphology and nanostructure of the LSV3 electrode. As it is obvious in Figs. 2a to 2d with different magnifications, the nanostructure of MOF materials was obtained by the LSV method which provides sufficient porosity. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) reveals the formation of nanoparticles in Figs. 2e to 2 g. According to Fig. 2 h, distinct fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.351 nm (region A) and 0.220 nm (region B) are observed which correspond to [021] and [022] planes, respectively. Additionally, the interplanar spacings of 0.206 nm (region C) and 0.293 nm (region D) are attributed to [331] and [202] planes of NiBTC MOF, respectively. These results are in accordance with XRD spectra and confirm the nanoporous structure of the LSV3 electrode. 3.2 XRD analysis XRD analysis was performed to characterize the purity and crystallinity of the product obtained by LSV. In this way, the modified Ni foams by NiBTC with different scan rates were compared by references [47,48] and as demonstrated in Fig. 3, the most suitable correlation between resulted in NiBTC/Ni was observed by applying 2 mV/s for electrosynthesis of MOF nanoparticles in comparison to other scan rates. As illustrated in other patterns, different peaks not only implied the presence of non-purity in the product but also showed non-sufficient crystallinity of the MOF nanoparticles. Major peaks found at 2θ of 17.29, 20.57, 21.89, 22.37, 24.97, 31.69, 33.37, 38.05, and 38.25° which corresponded to [111], [220], [111], [021], [400], [202], [112], [022] and [331] crystal planes, respectively. Slight deviations observed in the synthesized NiBTC pattern were acceptable in XRD analysis. This composition consists of zigzag chains of tetra-aqua nickel (II) benzene dicarboxylate which creates hydrogen bonding to fabricate a 3D network [47]. The crystallite size has been computed by Debye-Scherer’s equation: (1) D = K λ β cos θ Based on this equation, D, K, λ, β, θ correspond to crystallite size, Scherer’s constant, wavelength of X-ray, full-width half maxima of a diffraction peak, and diffraction angle, respectively [49,50]. Table S1 shows corresponding parameters calculated by this equation which confirmed the formation of NiBTC MOF nanostructure synthesized by LSV3. 3.3 FTIR analysis FTIR analysis was carried out and admitted the formation of NiBTC on Ni foam for LSV3 in Fig. 4 [29,51,52]. The observed peak at 724 cm−1 is ascribed to the stretching vibration of Ni-O. Moreover, other peaks at 753 and 1089 cm−1 are due to in-plane as well as out-of-plane deformation vibration of the C-H groups and stretching vibration of C-C groups in the benzene ring, respectively [49]. The appeared peak at 1375 cm−1 refers to the stretching vibration of C-O in the carboxyl group. Also, the peak at 1437 cm−1 is attributed to O-H bending vibration which is due to the presence of the carboxylic acid group in the structure as the linker of MOF. It should be mentioned that because of the stretching vibration of CO and the bathochromic effect, the resulting peak at 1720 cm−1 in H3BTC is observed at 1625 cm−1 [29]. Furthermore, the broad peak at 2800–3700 cm−1 implied the coordinated water molecules in Ni3(BTC)2. 3.4 BET analysis To investigate the inherent morphology and surface area of modified Ni foam with NiBTC (LSV3), the N2 adsorption/desorption was performed. N2 isotherm and volume pores (BJH) demonstrated in Fig. 5 exhibited that the synthesized NiBTC has an IV-type isotherm which implied the mesoporous network of MOF. Moreover, the H3-type hysteresis depicted the slit model for this loop. This isotherm exhibited no limitation for adsorption in high pressure of P/P 0 which is the reason for the non-brittle deposition of MOF nanoparticles [53]. According to pore volume distribution, the average pore size is equal to 3.91 nm. Also, 32.011 m2/g as surface area was obtained for BET in addition to 28.711 mm3/g as pore volume which is much higher than the reference [29] based on Table S2. 3.5 Application in HER The NiBTC/Ni foams obtained by CV and LSV methods were employed for the HER in NaOH solution (0.1 M). These tests were performed at room temperature with a scan rate of 5 mV/s. It should be noted that the potential versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) was calculated via this equation: (2) E RHE = E Ref + 0·059 pH + E 0 Ref As it is obvious in Fig. 6a, the modified Ni foam by the LSV3 has higher current density and lower onset potential than the others which illustrates the uniform morphology of MOF precipitations and implies that the presence of NiBTC on Ni foam can promote the performance of HER. Table S3 shows the data obtained from the LSV and Tafel plots (Fig. 6b). As demonstrated in this Table, among the modified electrodes, the LSV3 has a lower Tafel slope which indicates the higher kinetic for the HER on this electrode due to the great surface area obtained by the LSV method. This reason causes the reactions to be performed comfortably [54,55]. Also, this electrode has the lowest overvoltage (η) at 5 and 10 mA/cm2. Also, the EIS was performed to investigate the magnitude of charge transfer resistance for HER in the bare and modified Ni foam (Fig. 6c). In this project, the EIS was conducted in a frequency range of 105-10−1 Hz and applying −1.1 V DC potential with the amplitude of 0.01 V. Table S4 reveals the comparison of different parameters based on fitting Nyquist plot and Randle’s circuit. In this circuit, CPE is a constant phase element and R s depicts the solution resistance. As demonstrated in Table S4, the charge transfer resistance (R CT ) of HER for LSV3 in alkaline media is 3 times lower than bare Ni foam which again exhibited the great effect of NiBTC in the evolution of hydrogen atoms. Moreover, the greater magnitude of electrochemical capacitance for NiBTC/Ni is attributed to the promoted active surface area. One of the best strategies to determine the stability of the electrode in HER is employing the chronopotentiometry technique. Thus, − 20 mA/cm2 was applied to modified Ni foam by LSV3 in alkaline media for 30 h. As shown in Fig. 6d, the potential of the modified electrode didn’t alter after 30 h which exhibited suitable stability and robustness of the modified electrode. Hence, as illustrated in Fig. 7, the electrode morphology was examined after the CP test and active materials on the surface had suitable adhesion to the substrate with sufficient elemental distribution. The comparison between onset potentials in this study can be observed in Table S5 which depicts the predominance of the LSV method over the others [56–59]. It should be noted that the C dl of bare Ni foam and modified NiBTC/Ni foams were determined by Eq. 3 [55] and applying cyclic voltammograms at different scan rates ( Fig. 8): (3) C dl = Δj / υ Based on this equation, υ depicted as the value of scan rate and Δj is the difference between anodic and cathodic current densities. Fig. 9 illustrates the plot of Δj vs. υ to determine the magnitude of ECSA based on Eq. 4 : (4) ECSA = C dl / C s where C s is the specific surface capacitance (20 µF/cm2). Since, ECSA is proportion to C dl , a larger amount of C dl demonstrates an increase in ECSA which is due to the improvement of active sites in the substrate. Therefore, based on Fig. 9, the LSV3 electrode can promote surface activity. The C dl values for bare and modified Ni foams are presented in Table S6. 4 Conclusion During this project, different electrochemical methods were compared together to form a thin layer of Ni3(BTC)2 on Ni foam (at room temperature and short synthesis time), thus, the LSV technique with 2 mV/s during 0–3 V resulted in the best consequence. Moreover, no blocking of cavities was found on Ni foam based on FESEM results. After electrosynthesis of MOF on Ni foam, its performance in HER procedure compared with the bare and other modified Ni foams depicted the great potential of LSV3. Also, the current density and onset potential of the optimal electrode were higher and lower than the others, respectively. Furthermore, R CT for LSV3 in alkaline media is 3 times lower than bare Ni foam. In addition, according to the CP test, the stability of the optimal electrode is satisfactory and obviously, the current density for modified Ni foam is greater than the bare one. All of these results demonstrated that LSV3 has higher electrocatalytic activity than the others without blocking the cavities. In addition, NiBTC MOF can be used for further applications such as supercapacitors, batteries, etc. CRediT authorship contribution statement Ali Sadeghi: Formal analysis, Visualization, Validation, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: In this study, for the first time two electrochemical synthesis techniques including cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) were used for MOF synthesis. The Ni3(BTC)2 electrocatalyst was synthesized and deposited without any binder, for a short time and at ambient temperature on the nickel foam substrate. Morphology studies showed that the LSV method leads to preserving the 3D structure of nickel foam which promotes the catalytic activity. It should be noted that two parameters, such as voltage range and scan rate, were optimized during the LSV method. Moreover, X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy were used to confirm the MOF's structural integrity. Furthermore, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method verified the porous structure of NiBTC MOF. Additionally, the performance of bare and modified nickel foams was also examined for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) which demonstrated the tremendous potential of NiBTC/Ni foam in HER catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of NiBTC metal-organic framework thin layers on nickel foam by different electrochemical methods: A comparative study for hydrogen evolution reaction
